description: From Middle English chastisen, from Old French chastier, from Latin castīgō. See also the doublets chasten and castigate and cf. also chaste.

verbs.description: chastise (third-person singular simple present chastises, present participle chastising, simple past and past participle chastised)

entries.meaning: To punish (someone), especially by corporal punishment.
examples: and if his father had chastised them with whips, they must expect that he would do it with scorpions.

entries.meaning: To castigate; to severely scold or censure (someone).

examples: “Greg,” she lightly chastised. “You're not supposed to move your lips.” “Yes, I know. I'm a horrible subject. But do answer the question, Bella.”
